thread.title: Ashes 2015 score: News updates from the Fourth Test in Nottingham, day 1 | The
thread.title_full: Ashes 2015 score: News updates from the Fourth Test in Nottingham, day 1 | The Advertiser

author: TYSON OTTO
title: Ashes 2015 score: News updates from the Fourth Test in Nottingham, day 1 | The
text:
THE fourth Test is make or break for Australia.
Aussie captain Michael Clarke has never been under this sort of pressure and it showed at stages this week, highlighted by his exclusive column in News Corp newspapers boldly declaring he won’t step away any time soon.
It’s been a rollercoaster of a series and there are still plenty of twists and turns to come before either sides gets the honour of lifting the Ashes trophy.
Tonight’s first day of the fourth Test in Nottingham is set up fascinatingly with England one Test victory away from claiming the series.
8.38PM - MICHAEL CLARKE CONQUERED
Determination wasn’t enough to save Michael Clarke. Source: AP
MICHAEL Clarke tried to dig his heels in and rescue Australia’s pathetic first innings batting collapse.
He fought his way to 10 from 15 balls - the first Australian batsman to make it to double figures - but it was barely a speed bump to England destroyer Stuart Broad.
Clarke fell after edging to Alastair Cook at first slip.
It gave Broad his fifth scalp with the stunning figures of 5-6 from 3.1 overs and left Australia out of the contest at 6-29.
8.20PM - SHAUN MARSH AND ADAM VOGES FALL
Shaun Marsh failed in his return. Source: Getty Images
AUSTRALIA lost five wickets in the first 25 balls of the fourth Test.
Shaun Marsh became Stuart Broad’s third victim when he was caught in the slips by Ian Bell.
The West Australian batsman lasted just four balls in his return to the Australian team.
The man many thought Marsh would replace in the side, Adam Voges became Broad’s fourth scalp, when he chopped a thick edge to Ben Stokes at gully.
Stokes’ catch, diving to his right, was instantly praised by former Aussie Test keeper Ian Healy as “the catch of the summer”.
It left Australia 5-21 from 4.1 overs with Michael Clarke and Peter Nevill at the crease.
8.05PM - ROGERS, SMITH AND WARNER GONE IN FIRST EIGHT BALLS
Chris Rogers was the start of the collapse. Source: AP
AUSTRALIA’S Ashes campaign got off to a calamitous start, losing three wickets in the first eight balls of the day.
Chris Rogers was the first gone when he edged Stuart Broad to first slip Alastair Cook on the third ball of the match.
It was Broad’s 300th Test wicket.
Steve Smith was removed three balls later, edging to second slip.
David Warner was the third man gone, when he snicked an inside edge to keeper Jos Butler.
Australia was 3/10 and on the ropes.
7.35PM - AUSTRALIA’S SELECTION BOMBSHELL
Shaun Marsh has been re-called for the Ashes. Source: Getty Images
AUSTRALIAN selectors have rolled the dice on Shaun Marsh after sensationally dropping his brother Mitchell for the fourth Ashes Test at Nottingham.
The selection means the Australian batting order will get a massive shake-up with captain Michael Clarke dropping to No. 5 and Marsh stepping into the No. 4 spot.
It means Australia will have just four recognised bowlers to get the job done with Clarke confirming as much at the toss of the coin.
“Shaun Marsh in for Mitchell Marsh,” Clarke said.
“Obviously it strengthens our batting having a very good and an in-form batsman in Shaun Marsh and we rely on obviously three fast bowlers and Nathan Lyon as well.
“I’ll bat at No. 5, Shaun will bat at No. 4.
“It’s as big as every other game I’ve played for Australia. You can only do your best. You can only work as hard as you can. Now it’s about getting out there and enjoying the challenge.
“We have to bat well. I sense a similar feeling to what we had before the start of Lord’s (the Test Australia won by 405 runs). Now we have to come out and execute like that.”
England captain Alastair Cook won the toss and elected to bowl, sending Chris Rogers and David Warner out to the middle to face the heat.
England also made one change from the side that won the third Test at Edgbaston with Mark Wood re-called for the injured James Anderson.
